_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ES - 1.0  FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY



The owners, management, and employees of the Woodland Wholesale, part of Grow West (herein referred to as Woodland or the Woodland Facility) at 40189 County Road 18C, Woodland, California 95776 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.







ES - 2.0  FACILITY INFORMATION



The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Valley of Northern California. Applicable NAICS codes for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers).



* - Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) and aqua ammonia (NH4OH) are received, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients. 



* - Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in a 22,440 gallon storage tank (bullet).



* - The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume. 



* - Aqua ammonia (typically 24.3%) is received by truck and stored in a 75,000-gallon storage tank at the site. 





ANHYDROUS AMMONIA BULLET #1



* - Vessel Capacity:  22,440 gals



* - Maximum Amount of NH3:  19,074 gals



* - Mass of NH3:  98,040 lbs



The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 98,040 pounds.





AQUA AMMONMIA TANK #1



* - Vessel Capacity:  75,000 gals



* - Maximum Amount of NH4OH:  532,000 gals



* - Mass of NH3:  129,500 lbs



The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 532,000 pounds.







ES - 3.0  ACCIDENTAL

RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



SAFETY INFORMATION:  Woodland Wholesale ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered processes took place on August 14, 2019.



HAZARD REVIEW:  A hazard review of the ammonia processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The most recent update of the hazard review for the anhydrous ammonia process and aqua ammonia process was conducted on June 23, 2020. Results indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review updates.



OPERATING PROCEDURES:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures were last revised on August 14, 2019. Operating procedures for the Anhydrous Ammonia Process are certified annually, with the last annual certification on August 14, 2019. 



TRAINING:  The Woodland Facility staff, as well as Grow West corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The training program was last reviewed on August 14, 2019. The current training program is comprised of the following:

  1.  Initial employee training.

  2.  Periodic refresher training.

  3.  Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification.

  4.  Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training.

  5.  Training records for each employee.



MAINTENANCE AND MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:  The maintenance program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an

accidental release. The maintenance program includes equipment inspection, preventative maintenance, recordkeeping, and training. The latest equipment inspections were conducted on February 20, 2020 and the latest review of maintenance procedures was conducted on July 30, 2019.



RMP MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:  Operation, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility RMP Management of Change (MOC) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures. The MOC procedures were last modified on July 14, 2020.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW:  The pre-startup safety review (PSSR) applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre-startup safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MOC review. Additionally, a pre-startup safety review is performed in conjunction with the MOC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures. The PSSR procedures were last modified on July 14, 2020.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. The most recent compliance audit was conducted on May 23, 2019.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in

the event of an incident.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Woodland Facility has an Employee Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, as well as ensuring access to safety documentation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. The Employee Participation procedures were last modified on June 23, 2020.



HOT WORK PERMIT:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, Woodland Wholesale has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. The Hot Work Permit procedure was last updated on March 18, 2019.



CONTRACTOR SAFETY:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Woodland Wholesale Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. Woodland Wholesale also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the RS systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired and returned to service safely. Contractor Safety procedure was last updated on March 18, 2019.



OTHER CODE APPLICABILITY:  The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):



REGULATED SUBSTANCES

* - United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.38, Employee emergency response plan and fire prevention plans

* - United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA), 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter C, Part 6

8, Subpart E, Emergency Response



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

* - California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders 

* - Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]

* - United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia



AQUA AMMONIA

* - American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 31.3 Process Piping

* - California Fire Code, Chapter 50, Hazardous Materials







ES - 4.0  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.







ES - 5.0  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCP) was most recently updated on May 29, 2018 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.







ES - 6.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.







ES - 7.0  THE WORST-CASE RELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA WORST-CASE and ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 98,040 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the storage tank admi

nistratively limited at 85% of capacity. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and "D" stability modeling parameters.



AQUA AMMONIA WORST-CASE and ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 532,000 pounds of aqua ammonia. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and "D" stability modeling parameters.
